text: It's often said that predicting a price movement is somehow a different task to evaluating value against the outcome of an event but if you recognise that prices must trend towards 0EV you can see that predicting a price movement is simply a way of identifying a +EV price.

text: One of the standard techniques in modelling low-sample-size sports (NFL comes to mind...) is to benchmark your predictions based on the odds moves towards the start to measure how good your predictions are. You can use this to get an idea of whether your predictions are strong without needing to actually 'realize' the pnl on the outcome.

elements.text: One of the standard techniques in modelling low-sample-size sports (NFL comes to mind...) is to benchmark your predictions based on the odds moves towards the start to measure how good your predictions are. You can use this to get an idea of whether your predictions are strong without needing to actually 'realize' the pnl on the outcome.

text: Re. BSP - BSP doesn't sum to 1.0 usually, so not a perfect benchmark in most cases.

elements.text: Re. BSP - BSP doesn't sum to 1.0 usually, so not a perfect benchmark in most cases.

text: Thanks chaps - and just for anyone who might be struggling with this idea: It might be more obvious if you look at it the other way round, if a price is +EV that will generally herald a price movement (because people will take the +EV price), so if you want to predict a price movement you look for a +EV price. It's the same thing.

elements.text: Thanks chaps - and just for anyone who might be struggling with this idea: It might be more obvious if you look at it the other way round, if a price is +EV that will generally herald a price movement (because people will take the +EV price), so if you want to predict a price movement you look for a +EV price. It's the same thing.

text: The expected value of your bet is it's value at the moment it matches, it's not affected by whether or not the bet wins.

text: That's why it's called 'expected' value - it's the value you expect from a bet at the moment of placement.

elements.text: That's why it's called 'expected' value - it's the value you expect from a bet at the moment of placement.

text: The formula for the expected value of a back bet using decimal odds is: (odds * probability of winning – 1) * stake

elements.text: The formula for the expected value of a back bet using decimal odds is: (odds * probability of winning – 1) * stake

text:
While that is absolutely correct, I think the form

`[Probability that bet wins] x [Return if bet wins] + [Probability that bet loses] x [Return if bet loses]`

Is more intuitive

Obviously `[Probability that bet loses] = 1 - [Probability that bet wins]`

And, for a back bet `[Return if bet wins] = (odds - 1) x stake`

And `[Return if bet loses] = -stake`

elements.text: While that is absolutely correct, I think the form
[Probability that bet wins] x [Return if bet wins] + [Probability that bet loses] x [Return if bet loses]

Is more intuitive

Obviously
[Probability that bet loses] = 1 - [Probability that bet wins]
And, for a back bet
[Return if bet wins] = (odds - 1) x stake
And
[Return if bet loses] = -stake

text: I don't think you do get it. Your assertion that it's 50% is correct, if you make the prediction that it's heads you'll be correct 50% of the time. But if I said that it would be nonsense because from where I stand it's either 0 or 1. So our probabilities are different but we're both correct. That's because a probability isn't a property of an event, it's a quantification of how certain we can be about our prediction about that event. That's where you're going wrong when trying to bring whether a selection wins a race into it's analysis of it's EV at some earlier point.

elements.text: I don't think you do get it. Your assertion that it's 50% is correct, if you make the prediction that it's heads you'll be correct 50% of the time. text: <@U01C12ZEADQ> I am confused by what you mean here and your argument seems almost quantum mechanical - like the projection postulate where the state vector collapses to the component relating to the observed measured value but only AFTER it has been measured. The outcome does not devalue the probabilities of each state prior to the measurement. In an ongoing event, every second that passes gives new information so comparing an outcome probability at 2 different time intervals does not invalidate either measurement - an outcome can only have ONE probability associated with it at each time interval.

elements.text: I am confused by what you mean here and your argument seems almost quantum mechanical - like the projection postulate where the state vector collapses to the component relating to the observed measured value but only AFTER it has been measured. text: I don't think price prediction is simply a way of identifying a +EV price for the eventual outcome of the event. There is enough movement in the order book over, say a 2 second time period, that is uncorrelated with the actual outcome/current progression of the event. E.g. people swiping the book, lack of liquidity on particular sides and whatnot.

text: Just sounded like you were saying the two tasks are the same which I disagree with :sweat_smile:  one is modelling market microstructure (specifically if you do it over a small timeframe, e.g. 5 market ticks) whereas the other is modelling the actual event. The difference I suppose is that if you're betting on price changes 5 ticks ahead, you don't care _which_ of your trades are + EV /  -EV relative to the outcome of your event and believe that your model in general will lead to more +EV than -EV. As opposed to outright value betting where you aim for _each_ bet to be +EV.

elements.text: Just sounded like you were saying the two tasks are the same which I disagree with

which

each

text: <@U0128E7BEHW> I think you can factor out the extrinsic (order mechanics, people getting greedy, etc..) factors from the intrinsic probability. If your 5-tick predictor can understand which one is which you are golden. Otherwise I guess the expectation is that 5-tick change will be very short lived, but it's just not enough time for the market to incorporate all the information. Which was a bit of my argument that a change in price doesn't imply a change in probability especially in the short timeframe. Given long enough timeframe the extrinsic stuff should cancel out, though.

elements.text: I think you can factor out the extrinsic (order mechanics, people getting greedy, etc..) factors from the intrinsic probability. text: I'm saying that predicting a price movement is an indirect way of evaluating the expected value of a bet.

elements.text: I'm saying that predicting a price movement is an indirect way of evaluating the expected value of a bet.

text: Let me put this another way: Let's say I open 2 trades, one with a +EV bet, one with a -EV bet. Which is more likely to go in my favour? There may be sentiment or noise pushing  a price away from 0EV in the short term but the inexorable gravity of the market is always towards 0EV and this always acts on your trades no matter how few ticks you're going for or how short the time-frame. After all what is a big market move if not the sum of many small market moves?

elements.text: Let me put this another way: Let's say I open 2 trades, one with a +EV bet, one with a -EV bet. Which is more likely to go in my favour? There may be sentiment or noise pushing  a price away from 0EV in the short term but the inexorable gravity of the market is always towards 0EV and this always acts on your trades no matter how few ticks you're going for or how short the time-frame. After all what is a big market move if not the sum of many small market moves?

text: Or to put it another-other way: If you understand that to make a profit your bets must show +EV when evaluated against final outcomes (and if you don't I can't help you) and you have a model of any kind that produces profitable results then your model must be identifying +EV bets whether you designed it to do that or not because how else did you get them? My opening comment was intended simply to reveal how this comes about. Hopefully I've put it enough ways now.

elements.text: Or to put it another-other way: If you understand that to make a profit your bets must show +EV when evaluated against final outcomes (and if you don't I can't help you) and you have a model of any kind that produces profitable results then your model must be identifying +EV bets whether you designed it to do that or not because how else did you get them? My opening comment was intended simply to reveal how this comes about. Hopefully I've put it enough ways now.

text: I think it's slightly more nuanced than that. Say I forecast the price 5s ahead to be higher than what it is now. I lay at the current price. 5s later the price is indeed higher. I redo my forecast and now my model says "no the price will now drop". So I back. In both cases I assess my positions as +EV relative to price movement 5s ahead. I could not careless about the event outcome. The techniques and skills applied are totally different to looking at value relative to event outcome. You might say that your fair price for a horse is 5.0 and won't back it any price below that. Someone forecasting prices might say I'm happy to back at 4.9 because I expect the price to be lower than 4.9 5s ahead. And while this would be -ev position for you and you'd never take it, it's still a value bet for this person because they assess +EV relative to price movement rather than event outcome, and totally reasonable for them to take it. So I don't think it's fair to unify the tasks if they end up in scenarios like this. (Edit: corrected trade directions)

elements.text: I think it's slightly more nuanced than that. Say I forecast the price 5s ahead to be higher than what it is now. I lay at the current price. 5s later the price is indeed higher. I redo my forecast and now my model says "no the price will now drop". So I back. In both cases I assess my positions as +EV relative to price movement 5s ahead. I could not careless about the event outcome. The techniques and skills applied are totally different to looking at value relative to event outcome. You might say that your fair price for a horse is 5.0 and won't back it any price below that. Someone forecasting prices might say I'm happy to back at 4.9 because I expect the price to be lower than 4.9 5s ahead. And while this would be -ev position for you and you'd never take it, it's still a value bet for this person because they assess +EV relative to price movement rather than event outcome, and totally reasonable for them to take it. So I don't think it's fair to unify the tasks if they end up in scenarios like this. (Edit: corrected trade directions)

text: I think if we have two participants forecasting different things, and if a position for one person is value for them and the position is not value for someone else, then it's unlikely they are "doing the same task".

elements.text: I think if we have two participants forecasting different things, and if a position for one person is value for them and the position is not value for someone else, then it's unlikely they are "doing the same task".

text: I agree the eventually it turns out you are both looking for your trades to have +EV relative to the final outcome (obviously). But I don't think it's fair to unify them in such a way (as you couldn't use a 5s ahead price predictor to predict the final outcome of an event).

elements.text: I agree the eventually it turns out you are both looking for your trades to have +EV relative to the final outcome (obviously). But I don't think it's fair to unify them in such a way (as you couldn't use a 5s ahead price predictor to predict the final outcome of an event).

text: <@U01FJN59B52> has joined the channel

You're agreeing that your bets are +EV when evaluated against the outcome (and you're right of course) - how do you account for that coming about unless your models identify +EV bets? You might not have conceptualised that as being it's purpose but that's what it does.

elements.text: You're agreeing that your bets are +EV when evaluated against the outcome (and you're right of course) - how do you account for that coming about unless your models identify +EV bets? You might not have conceptualised that as being it's purpose but that's what it does.

text: You are mistaken in asserting that a bet can be +EV for one person and -EV for another, that's like saying both sides can make a profit. It may be that you want a -EV bet for some reason but it's still a -EV bet. EV is a function of price and probability, nothing else comes into the equation so you can't just go adding on other circumstances and saying that changes the EV because it doesn't.

elements.text: You are mistaken in asserting that a bet can be +EV for one person and -EV for another, that's like saying both sides can make a profit. It may be that you want a -EV bet for some reason but it's still a -EV bet. EV is a function of price and probability, nothing else comes into the equation so you can't just go adding on other circumstances and saying that changes the EV because it doesn't.

text: I think in sense I see it as buying a stock with a forecast of, say, a month. You buy cus you think it'll go up, and the next month, you predict that the following month will be lower so you sell. But you don't really have regard of whether or not 10 years down the line (analagous to the end of the horse race) the firm would have gone bust (horse loses) or become more valuable (horse wins). I see what you are saying though, I just didn't think it was "correct" to really say you're doing the same thing with both price forecasting and outcome forecasting. I concede though, since you are severely profitable :D I hope the example has given some sense as to where I'm coming from though.

text:
If I understand this correctly, you will make profit from value odds. Because you are using data (for example yellow cards) that the bookmaker does not include in their price. Or you have a better Model than the bookmaker. If the bookmaker would now include yellow cards and start using your model too, you will stay at +-0. Now you could say: “Ok, forget about the yellow cards, I will look only at the red cards(wich the bookmaker also does not include in their price for now)“. If the bookmaker includes the red cards too, you will not be profitable at both of these strategies anymore, right? Or the odds will move in an direction that the yellow card strategie will be now profitable at some point? Is it right to assume that the more data the bookmaker use, the less value can be found in the price? (Ignore the fact that bookmakers make mistakes) So any strategy will only work until the day your bookmaker takes over your calculations?(theoretical question) And maybe in 50 years there will no longer be a profitable strategy?
I don’t know if I’m understanding the price calculation right, so...! Also sorry for the bad explanation of translation.

text: <@U01EYDA8345> You will never get to the point where everything is modelled to perfection but this could be a philosophical argument as much as a tech argument. Perhaps if we can model things on a quantum level it could happen but in practical terms that is intractible. Even it if were possible, could quantum mechanics predict human behaviour such as corruption for thigs like match or spot fixing?? Maybe one day but we will all be in the ground by then!! As for using 1000 parameters, modelling favours less parameters for their greater generality. Consider a fairly simple mathematical example where you want to approximate a set of data using a polynomial curve - if you choose the degree of polynomial equal to the number of points, you get an interpolation (where the curve passes through every point) but this is seldom any good at predicting the general shape of the data points - better to choose a lower degree curve that is able to be acceptably "close" to the data. The first case is termed overfitting and building linear statistical models favours choosing SMALLER amount of parameters but ones that help "explain" the data wherever possible. I cannot speak for machine learning methods as I am a novice in that area. As for bookies they don't need to be that accurate in pricing (well soft books) because they will just ban winners. Pinnacle use profitable/savvy customers to adjust their prices accordingly but I believe that they have pretty good analytics too (just from what I hear).
